message: "Completing a game of “Super Mario Brothers” can be hard — very, very hard."
story: Mohammed Gamal shared Ken Smith's post to the group: Egyptian Geeks.
name: Ken
description:
Super Mario Brothers is NP Hard (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NP-hardness).

For my non-computer science friends, that means that it's basically not possible to make a program to solve the game in a reasonable amount of time.

The implication of this work is actually really interesting: if we can frame really hard computer science problems as video games, we can use human pattern recognition as a way to develop useful heuristics for solving them in reasonable time. Neat.

https://www.csail.mit.edu/super_mario_brothers_is_np_hard

data.message:
About the use of human pattern recognition that "might" help in getting reasonable (Polynomial) time algorithms for such problems .. I can't help but remember Scott Aaronson's Quote : 

"If P=NP, then the world would be a profoundly different place than we usually assume it to be. There would be no special value in “creative leaps,” no fundamental gap between solving a problem and recognizing the solution once it’s found. Everyone who could appreciate a symphony would be Mozart; everyone who could follow a step-by-step argument would be Gauss; everyone who could recognize a good investment strategy would be Warren Buffett. It’s possible to put the point in Darwinian terms: if this is the sort of universe we inhabited, why wouldn’t we already have evolved to take advantage of it? " 

http://www.scottaaronson.com/blog/?p=122
